articles.headline: Successor to Benedict Will Lead a Church at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI’s decision  to resign sets up a struggle between conservatives, who advocate a smaller church of more fervent Catholics, and those who believe that the  church can extend its reach.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI’s decision  to resign sets up a struggle between conservatives, who advocate a smaller church of more fervent Catholics, and those who believe that the  church can extend its reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Benedict XVI’s surprise announcement on Monday that he will resign on Feb. 28 sets the stage for a succession battle that is likely to determine the future course of a church troubled by scandal and declining faith in its traditional strongholds around the world.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: The 1040 Blues
articles.snippet: To an accountant, questions about tax liability are straightforward, but their answers may surprise people who are not used to such calculations.
articles.abstract: To an accountant, questions about tax liability are straightforward, but their answers may surprise people who are not used to such calculations.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN those who closely followed the numbing, eye-glazing and, at times, frustrating so-called fiscal cliff drama of late December — and people could be forgiven for tuning it out because it coincided with New Year’s Eve — find themselves trying to figure out the best angles through the tax increases wrought by the deal. And if they are not scratching their heads now, wait until April 2014, when they could see a drastic increase in their tax bill.

articles.headline: In Pursuit of Taste, en Masse
articles.snippet: If almost anything can be an object of connoisseurship, does the word still have meaning?
articles.abstract: If almost anything can be an object of connoisseurship, does the word still have meaning?
articles.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS didn’t always ask so many questions or expect so much in their quest for enjoyment. It was enough for them simply to savor a good cigar, a nice bottle of wine or a tasty morsel of cheese.

articles.headline: Slower Growth of Health Costs Eases Budget Deficit
articles.snippet: A slowdown linked to a weak economy and structural changes could help alleviate the country’s fiscal troubles.
articles.abstract: A slowdown linked to a weak economy and structural changes could help alleviate the country’s fiscal troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sharp and surprisingly persistent slowdown in the growth of health care costs is helping to narrow the federal deficit, leaving budget experts trying to figure out whether the trend will last and how much the slower growth could help alleviate the country’s long-term fiscal problems.

articles.headline: Waste Is Seen in Program to Give Internet Access to Rural U.S.
articles.snippet: A $4 billion federal program is extending high-speed Internet access to rural areas. But it is not always going where it is most needed.
articles.abstract: A $4 billion federal program is extending high-speed Internet access to rural areas. But it is not always going where it is most needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: AGATE, Colo. — The bank is gone from this once-thriving ranching and farming community on Colorado’s windblown eastern plain, as are the dairies, the hotel and the Union Pacific depot. The post office remains, at the corner of Main Street and First Avenue, the intersection of the town’s two paved streets.

articles.headline: A Database of Names and How They Connect
articles.snippet: Relationship Science is compiling a new computer database for the heavy hitters of business that lists a person’s associates, their political affiliations, their charity work and more.
articles.abstract: Relationship Science is compiling a new computer database for the heavy hitters of business that lists a person’s associates, their political affiliations, their charity work and more.
articles.lead_paragraph: It sounds like a Rolodex for the 1 percent: two million deal makers, power brokers and business executives — not only their names, but in many cases the names of their spouses and children and associates, their political donations, their charity work and more — all at a banker’s fingertips.

articles.headline: Airline Industry at Its Safest Since the Dawn of the Jet Age
articles.snippet: It will be four years on Tuesday since the last fatal crash in the United States, a record unmatched since propeller planes gave way to the jet.
articles.abstract: It will be four years on Tuesday since the last fatal crash in the United States, a record unmatched since propeller planes gave way to the jet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Flying on a commercial jetliner has never been safer.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: TV Show Mirrors a Japanese Battery Maker’s Bind
articles.snippet: The plot of the Japanese television series “Made in Japan” underscores the hopes the country has pinned on technologies like lithium-ion batteries.
articles.abstract: The plot of the Japanese television series “Made in Japan” underscores the hopes the country has pinned on technologies like lithium-ion batteries.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For many viewers in Japan, the plot of the television series “Made in Japan” was all too real: a struggling manufacturer, Takumi Electronics, turns to advanced lithium-ion batteries to reverse its ailing fortunes.

articles.headline: Shell Vessels Sidelined, Imperiling Arctic Plans
articles.snippet: The company’s ambitious oil exploration program in the Arctic has been hindered by delays for the last seven years.
articles.abstract: The company’s ambitious oil exploration program in the Arctic has been hindered by delays for the last seven years.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In another blow to its Alaskan Arctic drilling program, Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it had decided to tow its two drill vessels there to Asian ports for major repairs, jeopardizing its plans to begin drilling for oil in the icy northern seas next summer.

articles.headline: A Turbulent Tenure for a Quiet Scholar
articles.snippet: When it came to the major challenges facing the Roman Catholic Church in the real world, Pope Benedict XVI often appeared to carom from one crisis to the next.
articles.abstract: When it came to the major challenges facing the Roman Catholic Church in the real world, Pope Benedict XVI often appeared to carom from one crisis to the next.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Benedict XVI became pope eight years ago at the age of 78, many Roman Catholic scholars predicted that he would be a caretaker. He would keep the ship sailing in the same direction as his beloved predecessor, John Paul II. And as the rare theologian who knew how to write for a broad audience, Benedict would keep the crew inspired and the sails billowing.

articles.headline: Militant Threats Test Role of a Pentagon Command in Africa
articles.snippet: Created to train African forces and build social, political and economic programs, the Pentagon’s Africa Command finds itself facing a new generation of Islamist militants.
articles.abstract: Created to train African forces and build social, political and economic programs, the Pentagon’s Africa Command finds itself facing a new generation of Islamist militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIAMEY, Niger — Created five years ago to focus on training the armed forces of dozens of African nations and strengthening social, political and economic programs, the Pentagon’s Africa Command now finds itself on a more urgent mission: confronting a new generation of Islamist militants who are testing the United States’ resolve to fight terrorism without being drawn into a major conflict.

articles.headline: North Korea Confirms It Conducted 3rd Nuclear Test
articles.snippet: North Korea set off a nuclear test on Tuesday, its official news service said, and preliminary estimates suggested it was far larger than the previous two conducted by the North.
articles.abstract: North Korea set off a nuclear test on Tuesday, its official news service said, and preliminary estimates suggested it was far larger than the previous two conducted by the North.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea confirmed on Tuesday that it had conducted its third, long-threatened nuclear test, according to the official KCNA news service, posing a new challenge for the Obama administration in its effort to keep the country from becoming a full-fledged nuclear power.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Dell Faces Pressure to Raise His Offer
articles.snippet: T. Rowe Price says it opposes the $24.4 billion takeover bid for Dell as it currently stands, while Southeastern Asset Management has taken additional steps to fight the management buyout.
articles.abstract: T. Rowe Price says it opposes the $24.4 billion takeover bid for Dell as it currently stands, while Southeastern Asset Management has taken additional steps to fight the management buyout.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
